lg.l: An Indundation, says the Fable,
Ore'flow'd a Farmers Barn & Stable,
Whose Ricks of Hay, & Stacks of Corn,
Were down the suddain Currant borne,
Whilst things of Heterogeneous kind,
Together float with Tide and Wind,
The generous Wheat forgot his pride,
And sail'd with Litter side by side,
Uniting all to shew their Amity,
As in a general calamity,
A Ball of new dropt Horses dung,
Mingling with Apples in the throng,
Said to the Pippins plump & prim,
See Brothers how We Apples swim!
Thus Lamb renown'd for cutting corns,
An offer'd Fee from Ratcliffe scorns;
Not for the World, We Docters, Brother,
Must take no Fees from one another.
Thus to a Dean some Curate Sloven;
Subscribes Dear Sṛ your Brother loving;
Thus all the Footmen, Shoe-boys, Porters,
Abṭ Sṭ James's cry, We Courtiers,
Thus -·-·-·-·- in the House will prate,
Sṛ We the Ministers of State.
Thus at the Bar the Booby Betsworth,
Tho' half a Crown out pays his Sweatsworth,
Who knows in Law nor Text nor Margent,
Calls Singleton his Brother Serjeant;
And thus Fanatick Saints tho' neither in
Doctrine or Discipline our Bretheren
Are Brother-Protestants & Christians
As much as Hebrews & Philistians,
But in no other sence than Nature
Has made a Rat our Fellow-Creature,
Lice from your body suck their Food,
But is a Louse your flesh & blood,
Tho' born of Human filth & sweat, it
May not be said Man did beget it.
For Maggots in the nose or chin
As well may claim you for their kin;
Yet Criticks may object why not,
Since lice are bretheren to a Scot.
Which made our swarm of Scots determin,
Imployment for their Brother-Vermin.
But be they Irish, English, Scottish
What Protestant can be so Sottish
While o're the Church these clouds are gathering
To call a swarm of Lice his Brethren.
As Moses by Divine advice,
In Egypt turn'd the dust to Lice,
And as our Scots by all Descriptions
Have hearts more harden'd than Egyptians;
As from the trodden dust they spring
And turn'd to Lice infest the King;
For pity's sake it would be just
A Rod should turn them bact to dust.
Let folks in high & holy Stations
Be proud of owning such Relations.
Let Courtiers hug them to their bosom
As if they were afraid to loose them.
While I, with humble Job, had rather
Say to Corruption thou'rt my Father.
For he that has so little Wit
To nourish Vermin, may be bit.811-411P
